%text Let a binary operation $*$ on some \underline\text{non-empty} set $A$ be defined as $a*b$ The \underline\text{identity element $e$} is an element - or elements - in $A$ $(e\in A)$ such that for \underline\text{every} $a\in A$ \[ \qquad\quad a * e = a = e* a \text{ for all }a\in A \] Once again, $e\in A$. And the same $e$ satisfies the above condition for all $a\in A$ \underline\text{As far as your syllabus is concerned}, the above definition is enough. But it gets a little more interesting It is possible that $a*e = a$ but $e*a \neq a$. Or that $e*a = a$ but $a*e \neq a$. Or, that there is no $e$. Below are some examples % \begin{align} \begin{tabular}{NNNN}
\hline a * b & e & a * e = a & e * b = b \\ \hline a + (b-1)\cdot(b-2) & 1,2 & \checkmark & \times \\ \hline a\cdot (a^2-1) + b & 0,1,-1 & \times & \checkmark \\ \hline ab + 1 & \left\lbrace \phi\right\rbrace & \times & \times \\ \hline a + b & 0 & \checkmark & \checkmark \\ \hline \end{tabular} \end{align} %text %
